cool.  no, I hadn't seen it...and actually I'm having some trouble getting
that url to work :(

On Sat, 10 Sep 2005 04:40:13 -0000, Kenneth Stanley wrote
> Jeff, have you seen the roving eye OCR video by Derek James and 
> Philip Tucker?  They used NEAT to evolve an eye that looks at only 
> parts of an image and zooms on on relevant features to make 
> distinctions.  The eye actually decides where it wants to look, as 
> opposed to directed scanning as you suggest, but the concept is 
> similar.  The video is actually in the Files section of this group, 
> called "eye.swf."  Here is the full link:
> 
> http://f6.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/QFoiQ4hlWrnOq9A5E5Xs1IXAJvXaVNupa4hhQqv2
> udISn92F1PydEVJy1gKj2No6n-0oA7_ir95uFFOZbrG_1tOizxY_KIqSzu3K/eye.swf
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Haynes" <jeff@d...> wrote:
> > This may be an off-the-wall suggestion but you could try, just for 
> kicks,
> > approaching the OCR problem a little differently.  You could look 
> at one row
> > or column as an input vector and step the network through cycles 
> looking at
> > consecutive columns/rows.  Of course, this implies a greater 
> network
> > complexity, but it's a different approach if you're trying to cut 
> down on
> > inputs...may be interesting anyhoo.
> > 
> > Now someone else can say why this is a crazy idea :)
> > 
> > Best,
> > 
> > jeff
> > 
> > On Fri, 09 Sep 2005 23:08:00 -0000, Carl Strange wrote
> > > I kicked around a few ideas for a project, many getting wildly 
> out of
> > > hand, and settled on Braille character recognition.  It let me 
> play
> > > with a bit of development while using your OCR experiment as a
> > > framework.  I thought the reduced 7 X 5 input grid and very 
> distinct
> > > character set would be a snap for the network.  Now I know 
> better. 
> > > Thirty-five inputs and twenty-six outputs is too much for a one-
> to-
> > > one connected net so the problem isn't trivial.  I'm having fun 
> playing
> > > with the various search parameters, especially the frequency 
> of "add
> > > connections" and "add nodes".
> > > 
> > > The downside of adding an experiment is my SharpNEAT library and 
> some
> > > of the Form1 initialization differ from the standard release.
> > > 
> > > Lots to play with and I haven't even looked at the network code.
> > > 
> > > Carl
> > >
